habitat_description:
The distribution of the western black-headed snake occurs along the Coast Ranges of central California. Populations are found in the vicinity of Livermore and San Francisco Bay, south to the tip of Baja California (Cole and Hardy 1981; 1983; Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003). The area is characterized by the desert side of the mountains in southern California at elevations ranging from sea level to approximately 1220 meters (Stebbins 2003).

During daytime, this species is known to stay underground, under rocks, or under similar cover. It burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and vegetative litter (Natureserve.org).  Preferred habitats include desert edge, coastal scrub, oak and oak-pine woodland, thornscrub, grassland, chaparral, and other herbaceous terrestrial habitats. Populations are often established in rocky areas along streams, on both hillsides and leveled ground (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003).
